headline: Portman sides with McConnell against censure of Cheney, Kinzinger. Where local delegation stands on censure, Jan. 6 fights
author: Scott Wartman
sentences:
McConnell criticized the Republican National Committee for the censure of Reps. Liz Cheney and Adam Kinzinger and disagreed with the committee’s description that investigators into the Jan. 6 insurrection were going after people over “legitimate political discourse.”
McConnell called Jan. 6 “a violent insurrection with the purpose of trying to prevent a peaceful transfer of power after a legitimately certified election.”
On Thursday, Portman's office said the Republican from Terrace Park also does not believe Cheney and Kinzinger should have been censured.

“Never-Trumpers Cheney and Kinzinger donated to my primary opponent last election, who went down in flames for his racially motivated tweets, and they’ve been cheerleaders for the forever wars and domestic spying, both of which I oppose,” Massie said in the statement.

“The right to protest peacefully is protected under the Constitution and while there were lots of people demonstrating peacefully on that day in DC, there were also many who came up to the U.S. Capitol who were not," Portman said in the statement.

Rob Portman, Rep. Thomas Massie, the Republican from Garrison who represents Northern Kentucky, and Rep. Warren Davidson, a Republican who represents Butler County just north of Cincinnati, responded with a statement.

The Enquirer this week emailed Ohio’s Republican delegations questions asking whether they agreed with the censure and whether they agreed with the RNC's description of Jan. 6 as "legitimate political discourse."

Massie didn’t address the question of whether what happened Jan. 6 was “legitimate political discourse.” But he opposed censuring Cheney and Kinzinger, though he pointed out they donated to his primary opponent.
I also co-wrote a bipartisan report to help prevent it from ever happening again and supported the creation of an independent, non-partisan commission.
I voted to proceed on the House bill, but also advocated changes to the bill to ensure any commission was truly bipartisan."
"I believe Republicans share a common objective: Liz Cheney should not return to Congress,” Davidson said in the statement.
Other Republican members in Ohio and Kentucky won't say publicly whether they agree with the RNC or McConnell.
Follow-up calls to the rest of the delegation that represents the Cincinnati region were not returned.
Rob Portman has now sided with McConnell against the censure of Reps. Liz Cheney and Adam Kinzinger.
But where other Republicans who represent Ohio and Kentucky stand on that divide remains murky.
"I’ve been very clear in condemning the violent and criminal acts that happened on January 6.
Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell exposed a divide in the Republican Party Tuesday.
“However I think they have a right to always be wrong without being censured.
But they didn't directly answer all of The Enquirer's questions.
Davidson just sent a one-sentence statement.
Only a handful responded, including Sen.
Mike DeWine declined to comment.
Their voters will sort it out.”
Ohio Gov.
Sen.
